narendramodi.1503949521897746434: Today, India has many тАШMade in IndiaтАЩ vaccines. We have also granted approval to other vaccines after a due process of evaluation. We are in a much better position to fight this deadly pandemic. At the same time, we have to keep following all COVID related precautions.
narendramodi.1503949520127725571: In line with IndiaтАЩs ethos of caring for the entire planet, we sent vaccines to several nations under the Vaccine Maitri programme. I am glad that IndiaтАЩs vaccination efforts have made the global fight against COVID-19 stronger.
narendramodi.1503949518340964352: I would like to appreciate our state governments for their support towards IndiaтАЩs vaccination drive. Several states, especially the hill states and those where tourism is important, have achieved near total vaccination coverage and several big states have also done well.
narendramodi.1503949516575154180: Over the last year, IndiaтАЩs vaccination drive has been people powered. Unlike other nations where we are witnessing a lot of vaccine hesitancy, people here have not only taken their doses but also urged others to get vaccinated as soon as possible. This is heartening to see.
narendramodi.1503949514830344193: Today, India has administered over 180 crore doses, which includes over 9 crore doses in age group of 15-17 and over 2 crore precaution doses. This forms an important protective shield for our citizens against COVID-19.
narendramodi.1503949513106489347: In March 2021, vaccination was opened to those above 60 and those over 45 with comorbidities. Later, the vaccination opened for all those above 18. It should make every Indian proud that the vaccines are free of cost for those who want it.
narendramodi.1503949511311253506: In January 2021, we began our vaccination drive for doctors, healthcare and frontline workers. The aim was to ensure those at the forefront of the fight against COVID get proper protection at the earliest.
narendramodi.1503949509457375235: The manner in which our scientists, innovators and the private sector rose to the occasion is commendable. In late 2020, I had visited three of our vaccine manufacturers and got firsthand details of their efforts to protect our citizens.
narendramodi.1503949507721003012: IndiaтАЩs vaccination drive, which is the largest in the world, is science driven. We began work to create vaccines in early 2020, to protect our citizens and strengthen our fight against the pandemic.
narendramodi.1503949505699336197: Today is an important day in IndiaтАЩs efforts to vaccinate our citizens. Now onwards, youngsters in the 12-14 age group are eligible for vaccines and all those above 60 are eligible for precaution doses. I urge people in these age groups to get vaccinated.

barackobama.628974226364469248: "It is surely the pursuit of peace that is most needed in this world so full of strife." тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal

barackobama.628972310561558528: "President Kennedy warned Americans not to see conflict as inevitable. It is time to apply such wisdom.тАЭ тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal
barackobama.628971985045819392: "I have repeatedly challenged anyone opposed to this deal to put forward a better, plausible alternative." тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal
barackobama.628971616651776000: "When we carefully examine the arguments against this deal, none of them stand up to scrutiny.тАЭ тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal
barackobama.628971143148408832: "If Iran violates this deal, we will have ample opportunity to respond." тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal

barackobama.628969424855302148: тАЬWalk away from this agreement and you will get a better dealтАФfor Iran.тАЭ тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal
barackobama.628969117295378432: тАЬThose who say we can walk away from this deal and maintain sanctions are selling a fantasy.тАЭ тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal
barackobama.628968867461595136: "We will continue to have sanctions in place on Iran's support for terrorism and violation of human rights."тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal

barackobama.628968283492880384: тАЬAn argument against sanctions relief is effectively an argument against any diplomatic solution.тАЭ тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal
barackobama.628967974863396864: "Without this deal, the scenarios that critics warn about happening in 15 years could happen six months from now." тАФPresident Obama
barackobama.628967646831116288: "The bottom line is, if Iran cheats, we can catch themтАФand we will." тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal

barackobama.628966441530732544: "Iran has powerful incentives to keep its commitments." тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal
barackobama.628966157706354688: "This deal shuts off the type of covert program Iran has pursued in the past.тАЭ тАФPresident Obama #IranDeal

vitalikbuterin.1514103842266226690: Real life is similar, except (i) the "perfect-play" strategy is even more obviously intractable (you have to simulate the universe), and (ii) even the goals are less well-defined.
vitalikbuterin.1514103840135540736: You can't just keep telling a player to correct for biases and eventually end up with "as close as you can get to perfect play". At some point, you have to actually add content and depth to the strategy. And that content and depth will inevitably involve opinionated choices.
vitalikbuterin.1514103838164234243: You may even learn to avoid an entire list of specific biases that you know about, but there will always be *some way* to describe how your algorithm diverges from the perfect strategy that is forever out of reach to us mere polynomial-time mortals.
vitalikbuterin.1514103836234813441: Because we don't have the computational power to do perfect play, that algorithm will inevitably involve simplifications of the world, and opinionated choices of what intermediate abstractions to reason about.
vitalikbuterin.1514103834108342274: Sure, you can say "Alice overvalues material relative to position", "Bob cares too much about castling", etc. But you also have to talk about the *content* in the player's algorithm.
vitalikbuterin.1514103831906324485: Chess players, even at the top, generally use some combination of explicit strategy and illegible "instinct". But it's not useful to describe their strategies by talking about them as having particular biases separating them from some theoretical ideal.

vitalikbuterin.1508096148275404805: @glenweyl @PatrickAlphaC @theshteves @JonCo11ins The one-sentence explanation is that negative votes are key: if A and B are "the most realistic" candidates, and you like A, then you'll vote +5 A -5 B (and people who think the opposite about A vs B cancel you out), and on net that doesn't push C further back relative to A and B

vitalikbuterin.1478402834441908232: Paradox of diversity: if every organization within society must fully reflect the diversity of that society's members, then there can be no diversity *between* organizations in that society.
vitalikbuterin.1478402793031483398: Paradox of authority: you can't be consistent and believe authority too much, because different authorities frequently have low opinions of each other. So either you end up half-skeptical toward all, or you (intentionally or not) make your own choice of which authority to follow.
vitalikbuterin.1478402693676908552: Paradox of freedom: you can't be consistent and too dogmatic about freedom. vitalikbuterin.1343445497772613632: @SBF_Alameda Only the sequencer would actually "process" txs and compute the state. The key rule is: a sequencer *must* include *all* batchers that the collectors produced. The goal is that even if sequencers are highly centralized, as long as collectors are not, sequencers cannot censor.
vitalikbuterin.1343445227609026563: @SBF_Alameda The idea here is basically an anti-censorship tactic. Have two classes of block producers. The lower-performance class ("collectors") would just make batches of transactions; you could have many in parallel. The higher-perf class ("sequencers") would combine batches into blocks.

vitalikbuterin.1326738481490653185:
@__padpad @juliagalef Trustless trusted setup generator for all other schemes: obfuscate a program that contains a key k, and accepts an input program p, and outputs p(k) as long as there's a proof that p(k) does not reveal k

[ok I admit that last part is going to be hard to implement]
vitalikbuterin.1326737945995464704:
@__padpad @juliagalef Black box fields: obfuscate the programs `out = encrypt(decrypt(in1) + decrypt(in2))`, `out = encrypt(decrypt(in1) * decrypt(in2))` and the same for (-, /, =)

Note: can leave out the / to get black box rings instead
vitalikbuterin.1326737590070992896:
@__padpad @juliagalef ZK-SNARK: generate priv/pub keypair (k, K), obfuscate the program "accept (c, x), c=circuit, x=input_to_circuit, as input, check if c(x) = 1, if so, sign (hash(c), x) with k", and verify by just checking the signature with K.

This gives a 32-byte-long SNARK potentially (!!)
vitalikbuterin.1326737042366148610:

vitalikbuterin.1326445197526331392:
The magic numbers in the above code:

31556926 = seconds per year
384 = seconds per epoch
31556926 / 384 = epochs per year
64 = BASE_REWARD_FACTOR
31622 = sqrt(gwei per ETH)
x -> math.exp(x)-1 to account for compounding
vitalikbuterin.1326445129289224192: Note that this does assume optimal node performance; expect a couple percent less if some nodes are offline. But we expect few nodes offline because, well, it's not in anyone's interest to be offline.
vitalikbuterin.1326444925957754880:
Quick python code for computing staking reward rates from total ETH staked:

> def calc_annual_reward(total_staked):
   return math.exp(31556926 / 384 * 64 / 31622 / total_staked ** 0.5) - 1
 
> calc_annual_reward(524288)
0.25822791207
> calc_annual_reward(1000000)
0.18095530109 https://t.co/nuG83kkBDX

vitalikbuterin.1316294951106342912: To clarify, by "global" empowered executive I mean the idea that the governance mechanism gives a small group widespread powers over the whole system. The opposite is a *local* empowered executive, eg. a quadratic funding system providing $1m to someone who manages a team
vitalikbuterin.1316292848115871747: I think the fact that optimal governance of agile things and optimal governance of quasi-automata are different problems is missing from a lot of governance discussions.
vitalikbuterin.1316292846102605824: Thomas Sowell talks about this a lot: there is an inherent tradeoff between flexibility/agility on one side, and stability/dependability on the other side. Different systems benefit from being at different points in this tradeoff space.
vitalikbuterin.1316292844156411905: There are different kinds of governance problems. Sometimes, the thing being governed is *meant to be* agile, other times it's meant to be a quiet quasi-automaton, more like a court than a legislature. Eg. quadratic funding is more like the latter than the former.
vitalikbuterin.1316292842000539648: One important issue is that people often want decentralization precisely because they want a system that has strong resistance to changing in controversial ways. "Empowered executives" are a perfect tool to circumvent that, so they could be counterproductive to that end...

vitalikbuterin.1312905889725071363: So it's not "rollups instead of sharding", it's "rollups on top of sharding". That said, rollups are already here or coming soon even before sharding, and rollups without sharding still offer that 100x increase in throughput. So get on a rollup today!
vitalikbuterin.1312905888114515968: But the roadmap has an interesting unintended artefact: sharded applications by themselves need phase 2. But sharded rollups only need phase 1, because rollups use the chain only for data, not for computation. So we will have all the tools we need for 6400x throughput quite soon!
vitalikbuterin.1312905886327664640: Currently, we have ~15-45 TPS. Rollups offer a ~100x increase in throughput. Sharding offers a ~64x increase. These two stack multiplicatively; rollups *on top of* sharding offer a ~6400x (!!) increase in throughput.
vitalikbuterin.1312905884549300224:
The original ETH2 roadmap was created with 3 phases:

0. PoS (this is the one that's coming very soon)
1. Sharding of data, but not of computation (that is, the sharded chain will *include* ~2 MB/sec of data, but it will just be dumb data blobs, not txs)
2. Sharded tx processing
vitalikbuterin.1312905882330521600:
A quick recap of the short and medium term of Ethereum scaling.

TLDR:

1. Ultra-high scaling with sharding + rollups will be possible *in phase 1*
2. Sharding is NOT "cancelled"
3. Get on a rollup asap; you get 100x scaling even without eth2 https://t.co/fXW0Q3iAxu

vitalikbuterin.1300990496865546240: So what would happen? There would be more demand than there is space, so people would start bidding higher and higher txfees. vitalikbuterin.1300990493191409666:

The reason is: 465 gwei happens to be the current level at which demand (the number of transactions people are willing to send) equals supply (12.5 million gas of tx space in each block).

vitalikbuterin.1289834640983777280: @realLedgerwatch @AFDudley0 @cyber_hokie How does bittorrent solve the problem of "I want all logs from block 7m to today with topic 0x19cbd324, and I want them within 1 second"?
vitalikbuterin.1289834166943649796: @hasufl I think state provision is also a challenging problem, but history is low-hanging fruit and relatively safe to deploy new solutions in because relatively few apps depend on history (though rollups do!). Hence, history seems like a good place to start first, then move on to state.
vitalikbuterin.1289833713623154688: @realLedgerwatch @AFDudley0 @cyber_hokie Definitely great work, though it's not the same thing as what I'm talking about, which is a cryptoeconomic marketplace for on-demand querying of logs by specific topics, transactions by hash (or by account), etc.
vitalikbuterin.1289823658328768512: @_prestwich @wekabot I'm assuming clients know the current state; I'm advocating layer-2 infrastructure specifically for learning about *history* here.
vitalikbuterin.1289823517203079169: @_prestwich @wekabot I'm introducing a dependency on the *present* state to the security of the query about *history*. The fraud proof would need to provide a Merkle path from the missing log all the way into the current state.
vitalikbuterin.1289821762289414144:
@wekabot Fraud-proving that a set given by someone else is not complete is easy.

I'm explicitly proposing leaning heavily on cryptoeconomics for this.
vitalikbuterin.1289817525526515713: There's certainly quite a few people who have thought about such things, even implemented prototypes, etc, but this seems like an important area where we'd benefit substantially from ~5x more effort being put into it.
vitalikbuterin.1289817523144269825: Additionally, notice that in eth2 when the network is sharded, infrastructures of this kind basically become mandatory if we want to avoid dapp UIs all relying on centralized providers (ЁЯдо)
vitalikbuterin.1289817520967503873:
This has two key benefits to ethereum:

1. Clients could stop storing history themselves, and only store state (~5x storage size decrease)
2. Dapps could get more gas-efficient (many dapps are suboptimal gaswise today because they put things in storage to read them more easily)
vitalikbuterin.1289817518698201088: The important thing is that this could+should be fully decentralized neutral architecture, and being a provider should be permissionless.
vitalikbuterin.1289817516366127104:
Payment could be done through state channels: clients would randomly choose a provider, open a channel with them, and pay through the channel for each request.

If a provider fails to respond quickly, the client can just switch to another provider.

fchollet.1503412879491420160:
Tip #5: XLA is a linear algebra compiler capable of automatically fusing & optimizing TensorFlow operations, which can lead to significant speed ups for many model architecture / device combinations.

You can compile your Keras training loop to XLA via `jit_compile=True`. https://t.co/XlH2d7Nvew
fchollet.1503116972673810432: @V_Ravi_Chandra @awsaf49 Put data preprocessing layers in the https://t.co/oiMJsLvdrt pipeline if you want to utilize your CPU. They will be run asynchronously on CPU.
fchollet.1503103824369635332: @awsaf49 Pick the value that maximizes device utilization for your model and device. You'll find out in practice.
fchollet.1503089281023168517: @kelvindotchan The training schedule stays the same (unlike what happens if you increase the batch size, in which case you have to increase the learning rate)
fchollet.1503072856271327233: Tip #4: "step fusing" consists of running multiple steps of model training back-to-back on an accelerator device (a GPU or TPU) without syncing with the host CPU RAM. It's a great way to get to near-100% device utilization without having to increase your batch size. https://t.co/UrSZuLLz8l

fchollet.1498103551267991554: Testing is a tool for development velocity and reliability that will spring into action upon changes made by people who aren't you anymore, in situations you cannot predict in advance. Write your tests with this in mind. Defensively, and with great clarity.
fchollet.1498103033477021696: The main thing you want to keep in mind is that the purpose of unit tests is *not* to verify the correctness of your code at time t=0 (which is what junior devs believe). It is to ensure that all issues arising from *future modifications* will be caught and easily fixed.

And if you zoom in just a bit further -- nothing is certain.
fchollet.1488037240957661189: @paulmwatson A few km per second, depends on object rigidity
fchollet.1488036805454696449:
If you have a 4 km long brick, and you push it (you'll need to be very strong), the other end only moves one second later.

Whenever you push a rigid object, its dimensions change (until the compression wave settles down). Your brick gets shorter for one second.
fchollet.1488035929419698177: When you push a solid object, like a brick, it may seem like the entire brick is moving at once. In reality, your touch creates a compression wave within the brick, which starts propagating -- the other end of the brick only gets displaced when the wave reaches it.

fchollet.1487232887623544834: It's usually frustrating to try to discuss AI with deep learning researchers, because 99% of them are only familiar with the naive zoom level (single mind, single task) and have no interest in new perspectives or new formalism. Sometimes outright hostility. SGD or nothing...
fchollet.1487232038620971013: The key to problem-solving is to be able to move up and down the ladder of abstraction, to see the problem through multiple scales and perspectives at the same time. No particular level of zoom ever holds all of the answers.
fchollet.1487231712912285697: You might start modeling intelligence in algorithmic information theoretic terms. You might start refining your description of abstraction-generation down to a level where it becomes a step-by-step algorithm. But as you do so, don't lose track of the big picture.
fchollet.1487231299341283328: Zooming in involves breaking down the problem into elementary components and refining each component into its simplest, purest form, until the answer essentially springs from the problem formulation. What is the nature of generalization? What is the nature of abstraction?
fchollet.1487230607692206082: But zooming out and adopting increasingly systemic perspectives of the problem is only one tool in your problem-solving toolbox. It is useful but in no way sufficient. To make progress, you must also zoom in.
fchollet.1487230253877448705: And so to understand intelligence, you need to understand the dynamics that produced it in the first place. You need to understand the questions that intelligence is an answer for. That's the big-picture zoom level, the holistic view of intelligence.
fchollet.1487229926419795972: Then you can keep zooming out, and realize that bodies, environments, and cultures, are all subject to evolutionary pressures that have shaped their development, across different media and over different timescales.
fchollet.1487229365666533376: Thus, you cannot possibly grasp the nature of human intelligence without looking at the collective, integrated over time -- though you may be able to understand mice intelligence, which would be a start.
fchollet.1487228945095294976: But then you can keep zooming out: you can realize that intelligence is fundamentally social & cultural, both in the sense that culture shapes the mind and in the sense that most of our intelligence is externalized as cultural artifacts that we are mere users of and vehicles for.
fchollet.1487228841374281729: But you can also zoom out, and realize that the mind is in a body, in an environment, that it has decades personal history of embodied experience that has shaped how it works. So, to understand the mind, you need to look at the bigger system -- you need to refocus on embodiment.
fchollet.1487228279966691328: In that light, you're going to be focusing on situation-specific, task-specific rules. Which of course represents a set of problems entirely orthogonal to intelligence. That's the trap pretty much everyone falls into when approaching the question of AI for the first time.
fchollet.1487228278620377089:
When looking at a hard problem, you can either zoom in or zoom out.

When you approach the question, "what is intelligence?" for the first time, naively, you're likely to look at it at the level of a single mind, operating in a single situation. That's your default zoom level.
fchollet.1487162609073733635: Tip: if you're tempted to use evolutionary psychology to explain a modern aesthetic or cultural preference (especially one that is a few years old and region-specific), don't.

fchollet.1484328254320230402: This is true for cognitive abstraction as well. Intelligence is about generalizing to future unknowns, and for this reason it cannot be achieved purely by compressing past experience. To generalize well, you need to store far more information than what you have needed so far.
fchollet.1484327726219599877: And part, crucially, is that maintainability and extensibility require being ready for future needs that you simply cannot predict. To generalize to future unknowns, your code needs to be more general than its past and present scope of operation.
fchollet.1484326997803225091:
Part of the reason is that human intelligibility requires verbosity (you see this especially in unit tests, where DAMP is better than DRY).

Part is that compression focuses on optimizing syntax (the medium) rather than mental models (the message, what you actually care about).
fchollet.1484325961038385153: There is some overlap between compression and good abstraction (abstraction will significantly shorten and regularize your code compared to a naive approach), but the two often run opposite of each other. Good abstraction involves some level of verbosity and duplication.
fchollet.1484316577424035845: Compression, i.e. minimizing redundancy, is a poor heuristic to follow to generate good programming abstractions. Good abstractions don't make your code shorter, they make it easy to grasp (matching intuitive mental models), easy to read, easy to maintain and extend over time.
fchollet.1484265697152684035: The best tech products feel *simple* and *real*. Keep it simple, keep it real.
fchollet.1484238395945541637:
When you say, "I'm going to build X", remember that X is actually your starting point, not your destination. You will start with X in mind, then you will keep iterating, and you will end up with a successful Y.

fchollet.1475533926441656333:
If you think you've had some big insight, your first reflex shouldn't be "where can I find/generate data to confirm this", it should be "where can I find/generate data to prove myself wrong".

The faster you figure out why you're wrong, the faster you get to the next step.
fchollet.1475533566826225670: The reason why it's really bad to fall in love with your own ideas is that it makes you waste a huge amount of time in the end. If you care too much about the state of your ideas at time t, that actively reduces your iteration speed.
fchollet.1475532772802318342:
Anything that directly reduces your iteration time improves your output. That can mean:

- Getting better at programming
- Using a framework that makes it easier to experiment, that reduces cognitive load
- Adopting a self-adversarial mindset to invalidate your bad ideas faster
fchollet.1475532052627955721:
The more refinement cycles your ideas go through, the better they become. And the faster you try new things, the more refinement cycles your ideas go through in a given timespan.

So to get better ideas, you simply need to *try new things faster*.

Likewise if you're writing custom losses.

That's it -- the most important part is, remember to use the `weighted_metrics` argument in `compile()` if you want to apply sample weighting to your inference metrics.
fchollet.1471069668853129220: If you're writing custom metrics, you can leverage sample weighting by using the `sample_weight` argument in `update_state()`. Here is the AMS metric from the 2014 Kaggle Higgs Boson competition. https://t.co/E3Jna01e1Q
fchollet.1471068848879435778: You can tell Keras to sample-weight inference metrics via the `weighted_metrics` argument in `compile()`. These metrics will receive the `sample_weight` values at inference time. https://t.co/kOp354Vlgs
fchollet.1471068093506101248: However, in some situations it's still useful to apply sample weighting to your inference metrics during evaluation (e.g. if you want your evaluation to take into account the importance of getting different events right).
fchollet.1471067582493085707: At inference time (e.g. in `evaluate()`), usually such weights aren't available (because, in a realistic setting, weights are a type of label) and so they get ignored by your metrics. You will see unweighted metrics even if you pass `sample_weight`.
fchollet.1471067215709581313:
The 1st use case of this feature is to tell the model to pay more attention to certain instances during training, e.g. if you have an imbalanced dataset or if you're doing rare event detection.

The weight modulates the contribution of each sample in the gradient descent step.
fchollet.1471067213503373316: If you use TF Datasets, you can also simply pass a dataset that yields (inputs, targets, sample_weight). https://t.co/jlySs2Ck1N

Keras tweetorial: weighted losses & metrics. This is something I had to use recently...

fchollet.1469284163400384514: This is a pretty counter-intuitive fact. It has to do with the fact that while the *mean* validation loss is degrading, the *distribution* of validation losses keeps moving towards a more generalizable fit for a while.
fchollet.1469283727352205315: Related: it's usually good to keep training models a bit past the point of onset of overfitting (when the validation loss starts degrading). You get worse validation loss but improved accuracy, i.e. a better model
fchollet.1469283249226764288: This is especially tricky when doing hyperparameter optimization -- selecting your model configuration based on the validation loss is badly suboptimal. You should make sure to select based on the validation metrics you care about the most.
fchollet.1469282405420781569: In general there is no simple relationship between what you optimize for (the training loss) and what you care about (test metrics). Even validation loss is a terrible proxy: the model with the best accuracy or precision/recall is usually not the one with the best validation loss

fchollet.1463390553249173506: There's a bigger lesson here -- the important properties of a dynamic system can't usually be ascribed to any specific artifact within the system -- e.g. "is this piece of code (or data) reliable". They derive from the interaction between the different parts.
fchollet.1463388182125424641: By then, your validation performance has informed 19 choices that went into your model, and so that model is already the result of a search process (a training process, in fact) -- one specific instance among hundreds of possibilities.
fchollet.1463387661721210884: A slightly counter-intuitive fact is that the reliability of your evaluation method changes under you. The first time you looked at performance on your validation set, it may have been reliable. But by the 20th time, it no longer is. Even though nothing about it has changed.
fchollet.1463384475220393990: It's important to understand that there's no binary "either your evaluation method is tainted, or it isn't". It pretty much always is. What matters is how much. Always take your validation results with a grain of salt. The production data will look quite different anyway.
fchollet.1463383604675833856: Most people think of a validation set as a "weak test set": basically an evaluation set, but a bit less reliable than the final test set. It's more accurately a "weak training set": data that you use to improve your model (thus, on which your model will perform artificially well)
fchollet.1463369776508522500: I'll always stand with the builders, the creators, the artists. And that's why I'll always keep an eye out for the scammers, the takers, the exploiters.
fchollet.1463043983760756736: "time of onset of overfitting" can even be used as a quantitative measure of *generalization difficulty* between your training set and test set. The earlier overfitting occurs for a given model, the harder the test set.
fchollet.1463043626489974785: Overfitting comes from the fact that your test data differs in subtle (and not so subtle) ways from your training data. The more the test data deviates, the earlier overfitting occurs during training, and the more severe it becomes as time passes.

fchollet.1456395646408085509: Lastly: we really believe that the content of error messages is a critical part of the interface of a framework. They should be specific, informative, actionable. We've audited *all* error messages in TF and Keras (literally 1000s of locations) and improved everything we could!
fchollet.1456395307940388867: About the 2nd one: when an error originates from a custom Keras layer, the 1st thing you do when debugging is to print extensive info about the arguments that were passed to the layer call. We're now providing this context info by default -- as you can see in the image above.
fchollet.1456394887796908033: We're now filtering these out, resulting in clean and actionable stack traces. You'll find the root cause faster! https://t.co/pOTtjRUSwu
fchollet.1456394583424716800: About the first one: previously, stack traces would include many frames that originated from TF/Keras internals. They made it harder to find the information you were looking for and to understand what triggered the issue...
fchollet.1456394028778352641:
1. Simplified, more focused stack traces.
2. Displaying additional context information in errors that originate from custom Keras layers.
3. A wide-ranging audit of all error messages in Keras and TensorFlow.
fchollet.1456393887526707203: Debugging code is a critical part of the user experience of a framework. Easier debugging means faster iteration cycles. In this release, we've extensively reworked the TF/Keras debugging experience to make it more productive and more enjoyable, via three major changes...

fchollet.1450872831911206913: Unfortunately, the kind of prior knowledge we inject in this way is very weak compared to the complexity and unpredictability of most real-world datasets. As a result, deep learning models cannot meaningfully extrapolate except on very simple problems (special cases).
fchollet.1450872620119846912:
In practice, we encode priors in deep learning models in two ways: 

1. Architecture patterns (e.g. convolution, recurrence, attention...)
2. Data augmentation (random-yet-valid input variations)

They represent assumptions about the structure of your latent manifold.
fchollet.1450872336605802498: However, if you don't have such a prior, you are limited to local, interpolative generalization. You don't have sufficient information about the structure of the latent manifold to meaningfully walk out of the known area. https://t.co/MNIM1D0VRG
fchollet.1450871968702500865: The ideal case: if your model structure is shaped by a sufficiently strong prior, you'll be able to extrapolate. fchollet.1450567646265577473: @mlpeschl While DL might be able to attack some mostly-discrete problems with continuous embedding space (e.g. language), it seems to be fundamentally misfit for the task. fchollet.1450567323685822465: @mlpeschl I really believe that there are two poles within the space of all problems: discrete and continuous, with a swampy spectrum in-between. Perception (e.g. natural images) is very continuous. Prime numbers, very discrete. Most problems are somewhere along the spectrum.
fchollet.1450566882684071941: @mlpeschl It's complicated -- it's basically a fundamental question about the structure of information in the universe. DL only works with spaces where the manifold hypothesis applies (regardless of priors). The question is how far it really extends.
fchollet.1450559273931399173: @mlpeschl The entire subfields of DL architecture and data augmentation are about leveraging new/more priors in this way. And such priors are often about modularity! This is why we use "layers" or "convolutions" in DL instead of an amorphous soup of parameters.
fchollet.1450558909274476546: @mlpeschl Yoshua is right! The more priors you inject the less data you need to obtain a curve that approximates the latent manifold. Strong & accurate priors enable you to "see" further given the stepping stones (data points) you're given.
fchollet.1450550869351489536: @tdietterich The former only leads to generalization in the case where the data manifold is Euclidean (e.g. linear regression)
fchollet.1450549961003704320: @AMTraderX It depends on the priors encoded by your model architecture. More priors enable you to "explore" further around each data point, reducing the required data density.
fchollet.1450546358247563264: Typo: sparse. "a very sparse sampling of the encoding space"
fchollet.1450542031428751360: In conclusion: the only things you'll find in a DL model is what you put into it: the priors encoded in its architecture and the data it was trained on. DL models are not magic. They're big curves that fit their training samples, with some constraints on their structure.
fchollet.1450541521883721729: This is why *data augmentation techniques* like exposing a model to variations in image brightness or rotation angle is an extremely effective way to improve test-time performance. Data augmentation is all about densifying your latent space coverage (by leveraging visual priors).
fchollet.1450541160783441920: The practical implication is that the best way to improve a deep learning model is to get more data or better data (overly noisy / inaccurate data will hurt generalization). A denser coverage of the latent manifold leads a model that generalizes better.
fchollet.1450540673891913730: It's only with a sufficiently dense sampling of the latent manifold that it becomes possible to make sense of new inputs by interpolating between past training inputs without having to leverage additional priors. https://t.co/SmRvEN2NXS
fchollet.1450540392902914050: The second point -- training data density -- is equally important. You will naturally only be able to train on a very space sampling *of the encoding space*, but you need to *densely cover the latent space*.
fchollet.1450539992506195972: In this case, there is no latent manifold to fit to, which means that your curve (i.e. deep learning model) will simply memorize the data -- interpolated points on the curve will be meaningless. Your model will be a very inefficient hashtable that embeds your discrete space.
fchollet.1450539732555894785: You *cannot* generalize in this way to a problem where the manifold hypothesis does not apply (i.e. a true discrete problem, like finding prime numbers).
fchollet.1450539364795117569:
Being able to fit a curve that approximates the latent space relies critically on two factors:

1. The structure of the latent space itself! (a property of the data, not of your model)
2. The availability of a "sufficiently dense" sampling of the latent manifold, i.e. enough data
fchollet.1450539089023827969: The ideal model literally just encodes the latent space -- it would be able to perfectly generalize to *any* new sample. An imperfect model will partially deviate from the latent space, leading to possible errors.
fchollet.1450538829501251584: I'm back, just wanted to add one important note to conclude the thread: deep learning models are basically big curves fitted via gradient, that approximate the latent manifold of a dataset. The *quality of this approximation* determines how well the model will generalize.
fchollet.1450529880546832386: But by this point this thread is LONG and the Keras team sync starts in 30s, so I refer you to DLwP, chapter 5 for how DL models and gradient descent are an awesome way to achieve generalization via interpolation on the latent manifold. https://t.co/1luyISfgBY

fchollet.1450529427494871043: When you're dealing with data that lies on a manifold, you can use *interpolation* to generalize to samples you've never seen before. fchollet.1450528105412513797: A "manifold" is simply a lower-dimensional subspace of some parent space that is locally similar to a linear (Euclidian) space. (i.e. it is continuous and smooth). Like a curved line within a 3D space.
fchollet.1450528057433813000: The manifold hypothesis posits that for many problems, your data samples lie on a low-dimensional manifold embedded in the original encoding space.
fchollet.1450527813790883841: The fact that this property (latent space = very small subspace + continuous & structured) applies to so many problems is called the *manifold hypothesis*. This concept is central to understanding the nature of generalization in ML.
fchollet.1450527719083577345:
For instance, this is true for digits. This is also true for human faces. For tree leaves. For cats. For dogs. For the sounds of the human voice. It's even true for sufficiently structured discrete symbolic spaces, like human language!

fchollet.1434931441712832517: (Scams advertise risk-free rewards that are accessible to anyone -- no need to provide any particular value, information, or insight -- unlike traditional investing or VC)
fchollet.1434931069753565184: 3. Is the reward proportional to the risk? I.e. what are you arbitraging -- why would *you* be making money rather than anyone else? Investors make money by taking calculated risks and arbitraging information/insights. So, what's your unfair advantage? Why are you getting paid?
fchollet.1434930141172408320: 2. Are you encouraged/required to sell the thing to your friends/family? While there's sometimes an actual business need for hierarchical marketing, it's often the case that the requirement exists because *your friends/family are the product* -- without their money, no revenue.

fchollet.1433874555068502016: In our example, we kept the data augmentation stage in float32 (created before setting the global policy) since it's meant to be run on CPU as part of the TF data pipeline. https://t.co/2nRbBleVaZ
fchollet.1433873952829370372:
Use "mixed_float16" as the policy value on GPU, and "mixed_bfloat16" on TPU.

You can also configure the dtype policy on a per-layer basis using the `dtype` layer constructor argument. Useful to keep some layers running in float32 when necessary!
fchollet.1433873601808109568:
Tweetorial: using mixed precision training with Keras models.

All you need to do is set the dtype policy via `keras.mixed_precision.set_global_policy()`.

Example: training an ImageNet model on Colab's TPUv2 (for free!) with bfloat16 mixed precision: https://t.co/Ob7nDCmqnD https://t.co/K0AJWbxbMA

fchollet.1425164842722160643: @jordanestern @paulg At the same time, the classifier trained on old articles would *simply not work* on today's articles. Too many words/concepts would be unknown or redefined, and the style cues it uses would be outdated. It would produce largely garbage output (or at least very biased)
fchollet.1425164462651179008: @jordanestern @paulg The difference in ratings between what people could predict today (wrt current articles) and what people would think 20 years from now is not something that a classifier could possibly predict. So nothing is lost.
fchollet.1425164155623854085: @jordanestern @paulg There's no tradeoff here. You have to understand that such classifiers work not because they have a crystal ball, but because they latch onto superficial markers that are statistically correlated with evergreeness or not (e.g. lots of dates = not evergreen).
fchollet.1425160149472190466: @jordanestern @paulg What makes his proposal dubious is the notion of training on articles from past decades, which means the classifier would suffer badly from concept drift. The proper setup is actually to create a training dataset by asking people to rate *current* articles as evergreen or not.
fchollet.1425159808953376769: @jordanestern @paulg His proposal is not overly egregious. Predicting the evergreen character of a news article is a common problem and works decently well even with basic techniques (fun fact: I won my first Kaggle competition on exactly this topic in 2013: https://t.co/LqrHZmi5dZ)

b. Save it as a SavedModel -- which is a form of one-way export (of the TF graph) and won't let you reconstruct the exact same Python object.

A graph of layers is a data structure; defining and saving it as a data structure is the intuitive thing to do.
fchollet.1414670082224001027:

fchollet.1414669713217515521:
3. The model is a data structure, not a piece of bytecode. This means it can be cleanly serialized and deserialized -- even across platforms.

keras.Model.from_config(functional_model.get_config()) reconstructs the exact same model as the original.
fchollet.1414669085703606280:

fchollet.1414668058489069568:
Further, it's even capable of standardizing inputs to what it expects: if you pass data of shape (batch_size,) to a model that expects (batch_size, 1), it will just reshape it.

fchollet.1414667902045736968: 1. Because the model has known input shapes, it's capable of running input validation checks, for easy debugging: https://t.co/1B8E7GXmK1
fchollet.1414667159326715908:
But there are several key advantages of the Functional approach over the subclassing approach:

1. Your model has known inputs shapes.
2. You get access to the internal connectivity graph.
3. The model is a data structure, not a piece of bytecode.

Let's see what these are about.

fchollet.1414665804570796038:
Tweetorial: the Functional API in Keras.

Deep learning models are basically graphs of layers. Therefore, an intuitive API for defining deep learning models should be a *graph-definition API*.

That's what the Functional API is: a Python-based DSL for graphs. It looks like this: https://t.co/rthCY2Jqhz

fchollet.1412486860736143364: @d2smond Yes, exactly. In the general case, find what your fixed quantization step is (e.g. milliseconds, cents, or smallest delta detectable by your sensor) and store your quantity as an integer multiple of the quantization step.
fchollet.1412484842516664322: @AriDavidPaul The fact that floats use an exponent representation instead of a fixed quantization step is actually their strength. Just don't use floats when you need fixed quantization.
fchollet.1412484312146927616:
This means floats lead to weird numerical discrepancies that accumulate as you add more operations.

Only use floats if you want to run large computation with approximate numbers -- scientific computing, basically.
fchollet.1412483938237382659: And importantly, floats can't accurately represent base 10 numbers used for large quantities, like money. A 10e10 float is actually smaller than 10e10, for instance. Even 0.7 float is actually smaller than 0.7.
fchollet.1412483204284444672:
There are significant issues with floats.

To start with, float precision varies based on the number considered. The typical distance between consecutive two large floats is much larger than the typical distance between two floats close to 0. This can lead to surprising behavior.
fchollet.1412482841783373826:
Floats tend to be overused by programmers. Almost every real-world quantity (time, money, sensor readings...) is actually quantized, and is better represented via integers (ms, cents, etc.)

The only real use case of floats is scientific computing (physics, ML, simulations...)

fchollet.1409953526168449025:
@ethancaballero That is exactly what manifold interpolation is. E.g. producing a spork by interpolating between a spoon and a fork on a manifold of kitchenware.

Interpolation obviously does generalize to items not present in the training set -- DL would be useless otherwise.
fchollet.1409950064089337856: @tdietterich @__Phonix You can use 2-3 ex to synthesis a discrete program that will work with any possible list of ints, in any range, of any length. With DL, you'll need to first make the problem interpolative: train on millions of lists, then can only generalize to lists of similar length / ranges
fchollet.1409949429197524994: @tdietterich @__Phonix To do actual extrapolation from a few samples, you need a discrete model (like a computer program), not just a parametric curve. A simple example you can play with to understand the difference is list sorting: try to solve it either via program synthesis or via a DL model.
fchollet.1409949054230953984:
@tdietterich @__Phonix The only form of generalization you can do with a parametric curve (like a DL model) is interpolation, by construction.

The way DL solves "extrapolative" problems is by first turning them into interpolative problems, which requires a dense sampling of the data manifold...

fchollet.1407526941561810947: @mat_kelcey Anyhow if you have a small model and small dataset like you seem to, I do recommend skipping BN entirely. Will save you some headaches such as this one
fchollet.1407526729619427331: @mat_kelcey I guess this is intended by the authors to reproduce the ImageNet training setup. In general 0.99 is a good value for training.
fchollet.1407526521896542210: @mat_kelcey I just took a quick look at the MobileNetV2 code and I think I see what the issue likely is: the BN layers are configured with `momentum=0.999` which seems very high. It means you'd have to train the model for a very long time to get the moving statistics to converge...
fchollet.1407524705221763072: @mat_kelcey As a temporary workaround you can just set `bn.trainable = False` for each BN layer in the model, before training. This will force inference-mode behavior during training and will never update your layer (so effectively it disables the layer: it becomes pass-through)
fchollet.1407524361045610497: @mat_kelcey Anyhow, BatchNorm is evil (as you may have noticed), so try not using it. You could replace it with LayerNorm, or in this case just remove it entirely (for a small model it won't matter)
fchollet.1407523974347563011: @mat_kelcey That's the entire point of the moving average: you store in the model what the global statistics of the data look like, so you can use them at inference time when you only have 1 sample to work with (and therefore can't compute global statistics from a representative batch)
fchollet.1407519784309190659: @mat_kelcey The first question I'd ask is, what was your training batch size?
fchollet.1407519219877441540: @mat_kelcey So apparently there is a large discrepancy between these 2 values. This could be due to an improper batch size during training, or to the inference data having different statistics than the training data.
fchollet.1407518816888754179: @mat_kelcey Logically it can only be BatchNorm (only BN and dropout-like layers behave differently based on `training` value, and this model has no dropout). During training your model uses the current batch statistics and during inference it uses the moving averages learned during training.

fchollet.1397637516639887361:
The important questions, from the applied ML angle, are:

1. What problems can you solve using data reconstruction as your objective?

2. What automatically-generated or passively-collected alternative to human-provided labels can you use to solve task X?
fchollet.1397636067751170050: Now, from the standpoint of doing applied ML, the ability to solve problems without human labeling effort is huge. So unsupervised learning is a practical concept, but one that is theoretically irrelevant. It affects how you use ML, while being orthogonal to ML algorithms.
fchollet.1397636066908069888: What matters to progress towards greater generality in AI is *how* you learn -- for instance, gradient descent with parametric functions vs discrete search over a discrete program space. The supervision objective is an implementation detail. There will always be one anyway.
fchollet.1397636066283196417: The distinction between "supervised" and "unsupervised" learning is fundamentally superficial -- an artifact of the semantics of the last couple decades of ML. All learning is guided by an objective (including all forms of ML and all forms of human learning).

fchollet.1395127552881020929: @LucasEnkrateia So generalization involves *some* compression (a lot of it actually) but also a lot of work that's opposite to compression (writing down seemingly useless info that seems interesting / salient).
fchollet.1395127357258682368:
@LucasEnkrateia Such notes would have been very compressed, obviously: they'd have much less info than the original movie. But they'd have a lot more info than the shortest possible form of the notes that could answer the original questions.

These notes would be *generalizable notes*.
fchollet.1395127080002539524: @LucasEnkrateia Meanwhile, what if I ask you more questions later, and you try to use your notes to answer them? If your notes were the shortest possible, you can't. Do answer you'd have needed more extensive notes about what's important in the movie, not just the answers to the original Qs
fchollet.1395126797658771458:
@LucasEnkrateia Consider a simple example: I give you a set of questions about a movie, and you watch the movie and try to answer the questions. During the movie you write notes.

The shortest possible notes that enable you to answer the questions are just the answers to the questions.
fchollet.1395124680445423616: @LucasEnkrateia Now, obviously, generalization requires abstraction, which requires erasing irrelevant details, so your high-generalization system will be doing *some* amount of compression. But it will be storing lots of seemingly useless info as well.
fchollet.1395124406205042688: @LucasEnkrateia The more general point is that generalization requires you to store seemingly useless information at training time (info that doesn't help your training objective), that will become useful in the future (when generalization actually happens). That's the opposite of compression.
fchollet.1395124280229199874: @LucasEnkrateia There might be, but it will be by definition less optimal when applied to just English. You won't find it by optimizing for English.
fchollet.1395122951016443906: @LucasEnkrateia The most compressed model that does X is only capable of doing X. If it could do more then you could compress further.
fchollet.1395122834549055489: @LucasEnkrateia Because by definition compression discards all information that isn't relevant to the training goal, and by definition the training goal isn't what you want to generalize to (otherwise there is no generalization happening).
fchollet.1395122588074971138: @LucasEnkrateia Compression (with respect to a fixed training dataset) is by definition opposite to generalization. If you find the optimal compression dict to compress English Wikipedia it will obviously not be optimal for Spanish Wikipedia.

fchollet.1375546029815173120: The "how" stay at the level of superficial observations. The "why" gets to the heart of the system. It requires a full understanding not only of the system itself, but of the context in which it lives. It requires you to follow the thread of purpose that drove its emergence.
fchollet.1375545286924308483: A classic example is neuroscience: it is very much in the business of asking, "how does the brain work?", and it has no power to answer the actually important question, "why does the brain work?"...
fchollet.1375544630947815424: In the case of a piece of music, "how does it work?" will make you look for the key, the different voices, the rules. That's the easy part. "Why" leads you to ask what exactly about the piece makes you feel the way you feel. It will require you to understand your own mind.
fchollet.1375544196979888130: In the case of deep learning, "how does it work?" will make you explain backpropagation and matrix multiplication. But "why does it work?" leads you to the structure of perceptual space.
fchollet.1375543357880012801: When smart people are presented with something new, they tend to ask, "how does it work?": how is it structured, how was it made? 1D is 100%

lexfridman.1357429417388113920:
If you do a random walk in 2D, you'll eventually end up where you started with 100% probability.

If you do a random walk in 3D, the probability of returning is 34%.

These are called Polya's random walk constants.

Lesson: It's easy to get lost in 3D.

paraga.1135503614821060608: I am personally thrilled to have the opportunity to work closely with @mmbronstein, @frederickmonti, and the @fabula_ai team. Welcome to the flock, Fabula!
paraga.1135503614049308672: The Fabula teamтАЩs expertise in geometric deep learning is applicable to many problems at Twitter. The team will initially focus on improving the health of the public conversation.
paraga.1135503613059452929: We have a strategic interest in improving graph deep learning methods at Twitter as we build out a research group to advance the state of the art in machine learning.
paraga.1135503612329713664: Geometric deep learning aims to bring key ingredients of deep learning methods such as convolutional neural networks to non-Euclidean data, and the Fabula team has pioneered important work in this area.
paraga.1135503611436253184: Deep learning has been very successful in modeling images, video, and speech, all of which contain an underlying Euclidean structure. However, a wide range of problems at Twitter benefit immensely from the ability to model and learn from non-Euclidean graph structured data.

mkbhd.1359913559224963074:
Moral of the story: The octopus is one of the smartest, most capable animals in the ocean

But in the world of creative, independent media the octopus can grow WAY stronger and more powerful when the sum of the parts is greater than the original octopus. Keep swimming, friends ЁЯРЩ
mkbhd.1359913415905525764: Challenge: find out what your hearts are. Maybe that's the edit. Maybe that's the on-camera stuff. Maybe the writing. Maybe it's several of those. But those things that are integral are often hardest to define. Sometimes you cut off an arm, realize it was a heart and put it back
mkbhd.1359913221562511360: The challenge as a creator is to deliberately, methodically, intelligently cut those arms off and grow them into their own potential. BUT keep those 3 hearts.
mkbhd.1359913093321613314: That arm is PRECIOUS. You've always controlled it. But when you find someone to dedicate their time and energy and effort to controlling that ONE arm, they can get WAY more out of that arm. (Every octopus arm has a brain that goes with it btw. You can keep talking to that brain!)
mkbhd.1359912843987017728: When you eventually grow to point where you want to start scaling and building and hiring, there are tons of challenges, of course. Scaling a creative business is extremely hard. Because you already do EVERYTHING. It actually feels like cutting off one of the arms of the octopus
mkbhd.1359912746255609860: An octopus has 8 arms, three hearts and nine brains. The amount of control over multiple tasks and spatial awareness that an octopus has is insane. It's kinda like being a YouTuber (stick with me here)
mkbhd.1359912651514654725: Being a "professional YouTuber" is actually several jobs in one. In tech, for example, you're a professional video editor, writer/researcher, a professional reviewer and cameraman. Then you manage an inbox, accounting, content strategy, social media, and sponsors deals.
mkbhd.1359912438951510017:
Being a YouTuber is like being an octopus ЁЯРЩ
